comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those a
 
 <!--- OQS_TEMPLATE_FRAGMENT_LIST_SIGS_START -->
 - **CRYSTALS-Dilithium**: Dilithium2, Dilithium3, Dilithium5
-- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024
+- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024, Falcon-512 (PADDED), Falcon-1024 (PADDED)
comment.body: Is this naming prudent? It makes specifying this alg a bit of a hassle (escaping space and bracket if used on a command line; always applying CAPS lock). What about "Falcon-padded-512"/1024?

pull_request.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.diff_hunk: @@ -7,16 +7,18 @@ - **Authors' website**: https://falcon-sign.info - **Specification version**: 20211101. - **Primary Source**: - - **Source**: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/0657749a785db30e7f49e9435452cb042edb1852 + - **Source**: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/7707d1bcc8ae7f9ffd296dd13b1d76d2767d14f8 - **Implementation license (SPDX-Identifier)**: MIT ## Parameter set summary -| Parameter set | Parameter set alias | Security model | Claimed NIST Level | Public key size (bytes) | Secret key size (bytes) | Signature size (bytes) | -|:---------------:|:----------------------|:-----------------|---------------------:|--------------------------:|--------------------------:|-------------------------:| -| Falcon-512 | NA | EUF-CMA | 1 | 897 | 1281 | 666 | -| Falcon-1024 | NA | EUF-CMA | 5 | 1793 | 2305 | 1280 | +| Parameter set | Parameter set alias | Security model | Claimed NIST Level | Public key size (bytes) | Secret key size (bytes) | Signature size (bytes) |
comment.body: This change confuses me: The length of the artifacts created by the (currently named) "Falcon" algs change while the (new, padded) algs take on those lengths: Is this intentional? Isn't it surprising then that KATs for the ("original") Falcon algs don't change?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,72 @@
+# This workflow uses actions that are not certified by GitHub. They are provided
+# by a third-party and are governed by separate terms of service, privacy
+# policy, and support documentation.
+
+name: Scorecard supply-chain security
+on:
+  # For Branch-Protection check. Only the default branch is supported. See
+  # https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#branch-protection
+  branch_protection_rule:
+  # To guarantee Maintained check is occasionally updated. See
+  # https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#maintained
+  schedule:
+    - cron: '29 9 * * 4'
+  push:
+    branches: [ "main" ]
+
+# Declare default permissions as read only.
+permissions: read-all
+
+jobs:
+  analysis:
+    name: Scorecard analysis
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    permissions:
+      # Needed to upload the results to code-scanning dashboard.
+      security-events: write
+      # Needed to publish results and get a badge (see publish_results below).
+      id-token: write
+      # Uncomment the permissions below if installing in a private repository.
+      # contents: read
+      # actions: read
+
+    steps:
+      - name: "Checkout code"
+        uses: actions/checkout@93ea575cb5d8a053eaa0ac8fa3b40d7e05a33cc8 # v3.1.0
+        with:
+          persist-credentials: false
+
+      - name: "Run analysis"
+        uses: ossf/scorecard-action@e38b1902ae4f44df626f11ba0734b14fb91f8f86 # v2.1.2
+        with:
+          results_file: results.sarif
+          results_format: sarif
+          # (Optional) "write" PAT token. Uncomment the `repo_token` line below if:
+          # - you want to enable the Branch-Protection check on a *public* repository, or
+          # - you are installing Scorecard on a *private* repository
+          # To create the PAT, follow the steps in https://github.com/ossf/scorecard-action#authentication-with-pat.
+          # repo_token: ${{ secrets.SCORECARD_TOKEN }}
+
+          # Public repositories:
+          #   - Publish results to OpenSSF REST API for easy access by consumers
+          #   - Allows the repository to include the Scorecard badge.
+          #   - See https://github.com/ossf/scorecard-action#publishing-results.
+          # For private repositories:
+          #   - `publish_results` will always be set to `false`, regardless
+          #     of the value entered here.
+          publish_results: true
+
+      # Upload the results as artifacts (optional). Commenting out will disable uploads of run results in SARIF
+      # format to the repository Actions tab.
+      - name: "Upload artifact"
+        uses: actions/upload-artifact@3cea5372237819ed00197afe530f5a7ea3e805c8 # v3.1.0
+        with:
+          name: SARIF file
+          path: results.sarif
+          retention-days: 5
+
+      # Upload the results to GitHub's code scanning dashboard.
+      - name: "Upload to code-scanning"

Right

... Mostly ie obviously some of that setup is in code, and affected by commits

pull_request.title: Create scorecard.yml (OpenSSF)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Adds a github action to run the OpenSSF scorecard tool, and posts results to security->code scanning

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1706

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

This is a new CI action. It's only effect is
 - small amount of resource to run the workflow
 - creates items under Security->code scanning, visible to those with 'write' access in the repo

No branch protection rules are being changed to require successful completion of this action
 
 No additional testing is required
 
 Example output is shown in the referenced issue
 
<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [NO] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [NO] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

As per https://github.com/ossf/scorecard it's possible some additional permissions may be needed (depending on branch rotection setup).  These can be dealt with as a second iteration

This PR also does not attempt to address any findings from the scorecard scan. It's purely activating the tool so that we can review and act on those findings subsequently.

Draft for
 - testing
 - minor changes/comments cleanup

comment.body:
I can update the PR to be executed on merge only, and to just generate the serif for now. I'll leave the option to a) upload to scanning results b) post to openssf commented out.

We hopefully can then merge the PR.

I'll leave the issue open to track that followup discussion. I think the desired end goal would be to uncomment the two additional steps, though a final decision that we don't may happen too!

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,72 @@
+# This workflow uses actions that are not certified by GitHub. They are provided
+# by a third-party and are governed by separate terms of service, privacy
+# policy, and support documentation.
+
+name: Scorecard supply-chain security
+on:

+  # https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#branch-protection

comment.body:
> I can update the PR to be executed on merge only

I still don't quite understand why this should run during a PR/merge process: This seems to check (only) the "procedural" github setup not exactly influenced by code. Right or wrong? If right, I'd suggest running this only during the weekly tests (as well as at release). If wrong, I'd be grateful for an example of (code) problems this tool can point out and that a contributor can then fix during the PR process. Running only at merge seems wrong (either too late or too often).

> We hopefully can then merge the PR.

I'd prefer merging this only when we don't have a "red status" right away, i.e., the issues this highlights got fixed: This surely should not stall the next release planned for early next week.

@@ -56,7 +56,7 @@ For a full list of such options and their default values, consult [.CMake/alg_su
 
 ## OQS_ALGS_ENABLED
 
-Selects algorithm set enabled. Possible values are "STD" selecting all algorithms standardized by NIST; "NIST_R4" selecting all algorithms evaluated in round 4 of the NIST PQC competition; "All" (or any other value) selecting all algorithms integrated into liboqs. Parameter setting "STD" minimizes library size but may require re-running code generator scripts in projects integrating `liboqs`, e.g., [oqs-openssl111](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl) or [oqs-openssh](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh).
+Selects algorithm set enabled. Possible values are "STD" selecting all algorithms standardized by NIST; "NIST_R4" selecting all algorithms evaluated in round 4 of the NIST PQC competition; "All" (or any other value) selecting all algorithms integrated into liboqs. Parameter setting "STD" minimizes library size but may require re-running code generator scripts in projects integrating `liboqs`, e.g., [oqs-openssl111](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl).

Parameter setting "STD" minimizes library size but may require re-running code generator scripts in projects integrating `liboqs`, e.g., [`oqs-provider`](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider).

pull_request.title: Add Stateful Signature (XMSS and LMS)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Adds implementations of stateful signatures to liboqs for XMSS and LMS. The feature include new OQS APIs to generate key-pairs, signature generation, verification, and secret key state-management. Actual secret key storage is left up to the application.

This PR also includes an enhancement to OQS SHA2 API to allow handling updates with arbitrary length buffers.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ No ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ Yes ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
OQS provider support is a separate and forthcoming feature. This is separated because of the need to manage the stateful of secret keys.
<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,72 @@
+# This workflow uses actions that are not certified by GitHub. They are provided
+# by a third-party and are governed by separate terms of service, privacy
+# policy, and support documentation.
+
+name: Scorecard supply-chain security
+on:
+  # For Branch-Protection check. Only the default branch is supported. See
+  # https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#branch-protection
+  branch_protection_rule:
+  # To guarantee Maintained check is occasionally updated. See
+  # https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#maintained
+  schedule:
+    - cron: '29 9 * * 4'
comment.body:
By 'merge' I mean when code is merged into main, by the process of merging the PR.
The actual workflow trigger is on a push to main
Yes, these are basically procedural checks

The intent is simply to record the state of the 'current' code.

We could run weekly - though the resource taken by this check is very low in terms of github actions. 

Scorecard is an OpenSSF initiative. It's just a checklist to provide some assurance that the project is adopting good practice. In some ways it's like having a badge or certificate for what you've learnt. You already know it, but want to demonstrate that in a standard way. 

This change is absolutely not relevant for the release  next week. I think the PR should wait until after that in any case

The results (if we go with the change here) are only published to the serif file attached to the workflow, nowhere else. But if it makes sense to wait until the underlying issues are fixed, I could look at PRs for those, and leave this in draft.

pull_request.title: Create scorecard.yml (OpenSSF)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Adds a github action to run the OpenSSF scorecard tool, and posts results to security->code scanning

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

Fixes #1706

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

This is a new CI action. It's only effect is
 - small amount of resource to run the workflow
 - creates items under Security->code scanning, visible to those with 'write' access in the repo

No branch protection rules are being changed to require successful completion of this action
 
 No additional testing is required
 
 Example output is shown in the referenced issue
 
<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [NO] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [NO] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

As per https://github.com/ossf/scorecard it's possible some additional permissions may be needed (depending on branch rotection setup).  These can be dealt with as a second iteration

This PR also does not attempt to address any findings from the scorecard scan. It's purely activating the tool so that we can review and act on those findings subsequently.

Draft for
 - testing
 - minor changes/comments cleanup

comment.diff_hunk: @@ -7,16 +7,18 @@ - **Authors' website**: https://falcon-sign.info - **Specification version**: 20211101. - **Primary Source**: - - **Source**: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/0657749a785db30e7f49e9435452cb042edb1852 + - **Source**: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/commit/7707d1bcc8ae7f9ffd296dd13b1d76d2767d14f8 - **Implementation license (SPDX-Identifier)**: MIT ## Parameter set summary -| Parameter set | Parameter set alias | Security model | Claimed NIST Level | Public key size (bytes) | Secret key size (bytes) | Signature size (bytes) | -|:---------------:|:----------------------|:-----------------|---------------------:|--------------------------:|--------------------------:|-------------------------:| -| Falcon-512 | NA | EUF-CMA | 1 | 897 | 1281 | 666 | -| Falcon-1024 | NA | EUF-CMA | 5 | 1793 | 2305 | 1280 | +| Parameter set | Parameter set alias | Security model | Claimed NIST Level | Public key size (bytes) | Secret key size (bytes) | Signature size (bytes) |
comment.body:
The only length which actually changes is the signature length. The "original" / "currently named" Falcon algorithm produces variable-length signatures, so this length is only an upper bound. We had (incorrectly, per the spec) been using the size of the fixed-length "PADDED" format as an upper bound previously.

The behaviour of the "original" / "currently named" algs _does_ change with regard to KATs. In fact, the behaviour changes precisely so that Falcon-1024 now produces the correct KATs. Previously, our implementation had been out of sync with the KATs: see #1561.

pull_request.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those a
 
 <!--- OQS_TEMPLATE_FRAGMENT_LIST_SIGS_START -->
 - **CRYSTALS-Dilithium**: Dilithium2, Dilithium3, Dilithium5
-- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024
+- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024, Falcon-512 (PADDED), Falcon-1024 (PADDED)
comment.body:
Good point regarding the space... I went with all caps because that's how the formats are referred to in the reference documentation (https://falcon-sign.info/impl/falcon.h.html, starting at line 120). There are no uses of `strcmp` in `liboqs/src`, only `strcasecmp`, so I don't think the capitalization poses an issue. (I do see some `strcmp`s in the KAT test helpers, which I introduced—oops.)

How about `Falcon-512-PADDED` / `Falcon-1024-PADDED`? This is in line with `FrodoKEM-640-SHAKE` / `FrodoKEM-640-AES` / `FrodoKEM-1344-SHAKE` / etc. I'd prefer to have the format modifier at the end, as this really is fundamentally the same algorithm as Falcon-512/1024.

This space/paren/caps convention has already made its way into PQClean, but I don't imagine it will be difficult to amend.

pull_request.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those a
 
 <!--- OQS_TEMPLATE_FRAGMENT_LIST_SIGS_START -->
 - **CRYSTALS-Dilithium**: Dilithium2, Dilithium3, Dilithium5
-- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024
+- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024, Falcon-512 (PADDED), Falcon-1024 (PADDED)
comment.body: Hmm... If you are looking for smth case-insensitive using `strcasecmp` inside liboqs, you should beware of the TR locale. `Dilithium` with its several `i`s is especially in danger. In OpenSSL we had to introduce `OPENSSL_strcasecmp` to deal with it.

Hi, 

I don't mind changing the License. I remember back when I develop aarch64, it was Apache 2.0, so I set mine as Apache 2.0. 
If you want MIT, I can make it instantly.

pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those a
 
 <!--- OQS_TEMPLATE_FRAGMENT_LIST_SIGS_START -->
 - **CRYSTALS-Dilithium**: Dilithium2, Dilithium3, Dilithium5
-- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024
+- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024, Falcon-512 (PADDED), Falcon-1024 (PADDED)
comment.body:
> I went with all caps because that's how the formats are referred to in the reference documentation (https://falcon-sign.info/impl/falcon.h.html, starting at line 120)

This argument is somewhat weak as it otherwise begs the question why we don't have "COMPRESSED" in the (original alg's) name, too. And No: I don't argue for that!

> How about Falcon-512-PADDED / Falcon-1024-PADDED? This is in line with FrodoKEM-640-SHAKE / FrodoKEM-640-AES / FrodoKEM-1344-SHAKE / etc. I'd prefer to have the format modifier at the end, as this really is fundamentally the same algorithm as Falcon-512/1024.

Yup -- I always hated the Frodo naming :-) Superfluous "KEM" and (to me) unlogical: Most Algs have a "base name", possibly a "variant modifier" and then a "strength indicator". That said, Sphincs also deviates from this, so why not another one? :-/ My argument btw does not contradict yours: falcon remains the basic algorithm, so falcon-padded is just a variant -- in two strength versions.

Aha. That then has an implication for https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/362... (new OID necessary for Falcon-512/1024).

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ The list below indicates all algorithms supported by liboqs, but not all those a
 
 <!--- OQS_TEMPLATE_FRAGMENT_LIST_SIGS_START -->
 - **CRYSTALS-Dilithium**: Dilithium2, Dilithium3, Dilithium5
-- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024
+- **Falcon**: Falcon-512, Falcon-1024, Falcon-512 (PADDED), Falcon-1024 (PADDED)
comment.body:
> > I went with all caps because that's how the formats are referred to in the reference documentation (https://falcon-sign.info/impl/falcon.h.html, starting at line 120)
> 
> This argument is somewhat weak as it otherwise begs the question why we don't have "COMPRESSED" in the (original alg's) name, too. And No: I don't argue for that!
>

For argument's sake, "COMPRESSED" is the default format, so it's implied.

> > How about Falcon-512-PADDED / Falcon-1024-PADDED? This is in line with FrodoKEM-640-SHAKE / FrodoKEM-640-AES / FrodoKEM-1344-SHAKE / etc. I'd prefer to have the format modifier at the end, as this really is fundamentally the same algorithm as Falcon-512/1024.
> 
> Yup -- I always hated the Frodo naming :-) Superfluous "KEM" and (to me) unlogical: Most Algs have a "base name", possibly a "variant modifier" and then a "strength indicator". That said, Sphincs also deviates from this, so why not another one? :-/ My argument btw does not contradict yours: falcon remains the basic algorithm, so falcon-padded is just a variant -- in two strength versions.

The naming (presumably) has more of an impact downstream, and that's your department, so I'll concede. :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: `Falcon-padded-512` and `Falcon-padded-1024` it is. At any rate, this will be a moot point in the near future (hopefully) when Falcon becomes NTRU-DSA or whatever name NIST settles on for the standardized version.

pull_request.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
